title: Digital competence development course (Autumn 2023)
description:
#### Learning objectives
The aim of the course is to show the broader context of digital competences. We start from DigComp, which defines five areas of competence within which each citizen should develop. It tries to show how individual competences influence and change the information society and what impact their development or absence can have. At the same time, they also seek to deepen them in practice.

At the end of the course participants will:
- Define and critically reflect digital competences
- Work alone, even in a team with a European Reference Framework
- Understand the relationship of the information society and digital competences
- Engage in the development of digital competencies in specific teams
- Use appropriate tools for each competence area
- Safely use online communication tools to reflect data leaks and misuse issues
- Set your personal balance between work and study, between technology and nature. Students will be able to understand basic concepts of copyright.
- Students will have the basic ability to work with information and understand why information is related to power.

#### Details of the learning scenario

This learning offer is **asynchronous**, which means that it is an e-learning course.

Please consider a work-load per the whole course of 125  hours (25 hours/1 ECTS).
prerequisites: If you are MU student, please register course KPI33e in IS (Faculty of Arts), your ECTS will be recognised faster.

title: The Fall of an Empire or the Rise of Europe? (Autumn 2023)
description:
#### Learning objectives

In the traditional historiographical narrative, the arrival of the “barbarians” corresponds to the end of the greatest civilization of the antique Mediterranean: the Roman Empire. But was the situation so simple? Who were these “barbarians”? And did the Empire really collapse or was it rather transformed? The goal of this course is to focus on the artistic, visual, material, and performative cultures that coexisted in this extraordinary moment of history. To reach this objective, we will firstly focus on the prejudices constructed from the Renaissance to our days about what was commonly considered as the “Dark Ages”. Secondly, we will be investigating the role of medias in the transformations of visual history: from sculptures to “bidimensional” images, from roll to codex, from the illusive image to the iconic one. Third, we will analyze the role played by the meeting of cultures – constitutive for the investigated period – in the birth of the “Middle Ages”.

This course is taught by the Department of Art History at Masaryk University. 

At the end of the course participants will:
- be able to orientate himself in the visual and material cultures of the Late Antique to Early Medieval world;
- understand the tools and the importance of visual culture within social and historical phenomena;
- fall in love with art history!

#### Details of the learning scenario

This learning offer is **asynchronous**, which means that this is an e-learning course (e-learning materials + final essay).

Please consider a workload per the whole course of 125 hours (25 hours/1 ECTS).
prerequisites: If you are MU student, please register course ARTS006 in IS (Faculty of Arts), your ECTS will be recognised faster.

description:
**This offer has been postponed for the time being due to the recent events in Israel.**

#### Learning objectives

”My Culture and Yours: A Workshop Exploring Our Thinking, Languages, and Identity” is a pilot project hosted by the language centers of the University of Potsdam and Tel Aviv University—respectively the Center for Language and Key Competences (Zessko) and Center for Language Excellence (CLE)—to create a COIL version of a language café. Extending the invitation to partake in the workshop to the language centers and students of the EDUC partner universities of the University of Potsdam, Zessko and CLE offer a three-session COIL in which students will get the chance to explore their own definition of culture, reflect on their own language and cultural background, practice communicating in English, and become acquainted with the new cultures and stories from their fellow participants. These themes will be mediated in story-telling and predominantly oral activities. In this virtual learning setting, students enhance their language proficiency in English as well as their intercultural communicative competence and are asked 1) to  embrace the opportunities that come with experiencing cultural diversity and 2) to then answer the overarching core question of this workshop about one’s own cultural identity; 3) to respect individual difference and shared global values, and 4) to ultimately rise to the EDUC’s mission statement of creating an inclusive and diverse digital space for intercultural exchange and discourse.

title: Writing Across Cultures (English Academic Writing II) (Autumn 2023)
description:
#### Learning objectives

Taking the UNESCO working paper "Intercultural Competence: Conceptual and Operational Framework" (Leeds-Hurwitzand Stenou, 2013) as a springboard, we investigate the meaning and relevance of intercultural competence in today's world. Students then research and write about a topic of their choosing that is related to intercultural competence. Exercises that develop students' peer review skills will help them to identify and correct errors in their peers' and in their own writing. We view writing squarely as a process and consequently do portfolio work over the course of the semester. The semester culminates in a short presentation of the students' essays.
**We welcome students in the EDUC alliance to participate in some of the sessions (for no ECTS points) or for all of the sessions (an EDUC Certificate stating 90 hours as workload, equivalent to 3 ECTS).** In both cases, students will be issued an EDUC certificate. **Passive participants will be removed from the Moodle course.**

This two-hour writing course centers on essay writing and the argumentative essay in particular. Upon completion of this course, students will be able
- to express themselves using nuanced language (improved accuracy and appropriacy of writing)
- to produce cohesive and coherent academic writing (improved complexity and effectiveness of writing)
- to identify and produce various types of academic texts
- to evaluate their own and others' texts (peer review)
- to assess and cite (MLA) appropriate sources properly

Students are strongly encouraged to consult with the Writing Assistance Program at Zessko (this is not a course tutorial).

title: INTERFACE: English Oral Proficiency and Intercultural Competence
description:
#### Learning objectives
INTERFACE (INTERculural proFiciency and orAl Competence in English) is a model project of social online teaching and learning. Since 2020, it has brought together about 300  B.A. English and B.Ed. English students from the University of Potsdam and Beit Berl College (Israel) and provides these students with opportunities to experience virtual collaboration. The course instructors in Germany and Israel (originally from the USA, South Africa, and Great Britain) focus on improving students’ oral proficiency in English (accuracy, fluency, pronunciation), and participants have been able to attain a high proficiency in the main communicative language competences as outlined in the CEFR.
What is more, INTERFACE presents a form of didactic modeling, which is especially important for future educators. Student participants are encouraged to take an active role in this online project and thus have have a degree of autonomy  (cf. UP Mission Statement for Teaching and Learning, “4. Target group-specific teaching”). They can select which digital tools work best for them, reflect on alternative assessment models (tasks and rubrics), and decide what constitutes authentic learning and a safe online learning environment. In doing so, they grow to understand the importance of collaboration and innovation. By working in English with speakers of Arabic, Hebrew, German, and other languages, the students question their ideas of the “Other” and grow to embrace diversity.  Furthermore, the project also prepares the students with skills for life and the workforce, such as flexibility and adaptability, social and cross-cultural skills, and accountability and responsibility (cf. UP Mission Statement for Teaching and Learning, “2. Career orientation and personal development”). 
**We welcome students in the EDUC alliance to participate in some of the sessions (for no ECTS points) or for all of the sessions (an EDUC certificate stating 90 hours as workload, equivalent to 3 ECTS).** In both cases, students will be issued an EDUC certificate. **Passive participants will be removed from the Moodle course.** 

Upon successful completion of this course, students should be able to:

- recognize and practice appropriate articulation of English phonemes
- raise awareness of and practise the suprasegmental features of English, including stress and intonation patterns, as well as connected speech
- learn how to identify interference from one’s native language and develop skills for speaking intelligibly
- recognize and comprehend a variety of accents to navigate different communicative contexts
- discuss relevant topics with the goal of engaging in meaningful discourse in different contexts (e.g. presentations and interviews)
- gain insight into the interconnection between pronunciation and non-verbal behaviour in conveying and interpreting meaning, particularly when giving academic presentations.

title: German A1.2 (Autumn 2023)
description:
#### Learning objectives

The course is aimed at learners who would like to begin studying German or go further after having taken a very few initial steps, – be it informal out-of-classroom learning, more formal in an A1.1 course or self-directed online learning with Zessko’s [“German A1 Starter”] (https://courses.educalliance.eu/course/165) on the EDUC Moodle. 
Built on an action-orientated approach and a fully Moodle-based online learning material, it addresses reception, production, interaction and mediation in terms of language activities in connection to language strategies in various, but typical areas of communication related to academic life in Potsdam. Consequently, it does neither claim to “cover” the whole level A1 according to the CEFR nor to provide A1 exam training but instead to empower successful participants to take their first steps in a German speaking surrounding and – equally important – to manage their further language acquisition.

Upon successfully engaging in this course, learners:
- can recognise concrete information (e.g. places and times) on familiar topics encountered in everyday life, provided it is delivered slowly and clearly.
- can understand some expressions when people are discussing them: personal and academic life, hobbies or surroundings, provided the delivery is slow and clear.
- can understand instructions addressed carefully and slowly to them and follow short, simple directions.
- can understand very short, simple texts a single phrase at a time, picking up familiar names, words and basic phrases.
- can guess the probable meaning of an unknown word/sign that is similar to one in the language they normally use.
- can produce simple, mainly isolated phrases about people, time and places.
- can ask and answer simple questions, initiate and respond to simple statements in areas of immediate need or on very familiar topics.
- can make an introduction and use basic greeting and leave-taking expressions.
- can ask for food and drink using basic expressions.
- can handle numbers, quantities, cost and time (can-do statements according to the CEFR).

#### Details of the learning scenario

Mode: Flipped classroom with asynchronous individual learning through Moodle (instruction, exercises and quizzes, assignments) + regular video meetings via Zoom (collaborative task-based learning) according to participants’ progress with the individual learning (admission to meetings may be linked to the assignments).

**Workload: 180 h (*equivalent to 6 ECTS)**

#### Schedule/Timetable of the learning offer

Starting: 19/10/2023
End: 09/02/2024
Exam: most likely 8th February 2024
Live sessions:
**Thursdays: 16:00 - 19:30 h, weekly**
prerequisites:
Enrolment at any of the EDUC universities
Please do only apply if 
- you can virtually attend the sessions on Thursdays from 4pm – 7:30 pm – you need to have access to a computer with a rather large screen, a camera and a microphone (good quality headset preferred) - and
- you can spend at least 8 hours per week on the individual learning (see “Details of the learning scenario”).

title: Islands of (the) Enlightenment
description:
#### Learning objectives

The Seminar will deal with questions of the inter-relation of the spatial category of islands with intellectual phenomena linked to the Enlightenment with regard to different dimensions:
- Island Literatures of the 18th Century and beyond: the Early Modern Genre of Island Utopias is continued and transformed in the 18th Century and forms a wide-spread genre in the different European contexts (beginning with Daniel Defoe’s “Robinson Crusoe” and its European reception in works such as J.G. Schnabels “Insel Felsenburg” leading to Denis Diderots “Supplement au voyage de Bougainville” in France or Wilhelm Heinses “Glückselige Inseln” in Germany). Connected to this are crucial discourses of the Enlightenment on social and economic reforms, questions of colonialism and Euro-centrism etc.
- Political significance of Islands and the Haitian Revolution: in the (colonial) system of World Powers islands played a crucial role. The Haitian Revolution of 1790ff. is the major event which inspired questions on the relation of Enlightenment and colonialism until today.
- In the philosophical discourses of the Enlightenment the “island” understood in a broader metaphorical sense is a central motive on different levels (epistemology, political philosophy, social philosophy, economy etc.) These are ranging from indigene cartographies from the Pacifics up to the methodological individualism in Adam Smith’ “The Wealth of Nations”.
The aim of the Summer School is to bring together the various research clusters at the EDUC partner universities. At least at the universities of Potsdam, Cagliari, and Paris Nanterre there are existing internationally visible research foci related to the topic which promise fruitful synergies and we invite further EDUC partner universities to participate.

Three main topics have been defined so far:
1. Island Literatures
The participants will learn about European literatures of the 18th Century and the crucial position of islands for the development of Enlightenment's genres (from Daniel Defoe's Robinson Crusoe on).

2. Island Epistemologies
The participants will learn to reflect the role of islands (as a topographical concept as well as in a metaphorical sense) for epistemological models of the Enlightenment (from Bacon's Nova Atlantis to Adam Smith's methodological individualism)

3. Island Politics: The participants will learn about the role of Islands in the colonial system of the 18th Century and their significance as contact zone of European and extra-European cultures in the development of key concepts of the Enlightenment (like in Diderot's writings on Tahiti or in the Haitian Enlightenment)

#### Details of the learning scenario:

This learning offer is a blended research summer school, which means eight weeks of online learning with one live session per week plus one week of on site-program at the university of Potsdam.

Please consider a total workload of: 90 hours.

The minimum technical requirements you need to participate are: e.g.: Zoom account.

title: Initiation to Research and Critical Thinking - February to May 2024
description:
🎯 General goal:
Discover research in its many aspects and start learning the basics of it. This course is made up by eight sections with a specific theme, its own documents, lectures and activities to follow by yourself, at your own pace!

🎓 Assessment and recognition:
Completing all 8 sections can grant you 1 extra ECTS on your current curriculum. To do so, you must complete all the assessments offered in each section. This also implies to consult and achieve all mandatory activities.

Be aware that ECTS are not directly given by EDUC or one of our Universities. A certificate will be issued to participants who successfully completed all the sections to request their home University to recognize the ECTS. >Please refer to your local EDUC team to get more information on this topic.

⏳ Duration: 
Approximately 10 weeks - Course open from 22/02/24 to 02/05/24

👩‍💻 Working load: Approximately 25 hours 

🎯 Course objectives:
Section 1: Identifying a scientific question and its elements / Section 2: Knowing and using bibliographic research processes and tools / Section 3: Knowing and selecting the appropriate tools to solve a scientific question / Section 4: Understanding the basics of scientific integrity / Section 5:Understanding the functioning of research professions in the EU and EDUC / Section 6: Understanding the functioning of European research projects / Section 7:Understanding the functioning of research presentation / Section 8: Understanding the basics of critical thinking applied to research

🎁 Bachelor students successfully completing the course will be offered the opportunity to apply for a 1 week observation internship at one of the EDUC research laboratory.

title: BRSS Circular Bioeconomy for Sustainable Waste Management and Resource Recovery
description:
#### Please **apply on the link of your home University** below 👇
 
The BRSS, titled "Circular Bioeconomy for Sustainable Waste Management and Resource Recovery," is dedicated to exploring and advancing innovative solutions for sustainable waste management. This program provides a unique opportunity to intersect cutting-edge research, innovation, and practical applications in the field of circular bioeconomy.
The research summer school will take place virtually in May (6-17) 2024, while the in-person sessions will be held at the University of Cagliari - Campus Engineering in June (10-14) 2024.
The course is held in English and is structured to ensure a rich and comprehensive learning experience for participants, including:
-	Lectures;
-	Teamwork activities;
-	Field Visits (technical and cultural);
-	Interactive Discussions, Case Studies, and Debates;
-	Networking Events and Social Gatherings. 
-	Final Presentations

title: Understanding Regulation, Theory and Practice (2023-2024)
description:
####Learning objectives

Regulations have tremendous impacts on economic growth and the well-being of humans. 

Indeed, they shape economic systems. It is thus required for policy makers and regulators to understand and gain a firm grounding in the key features of regulation:

-Why are we regulating? 

-How should we regulate? 

-How regulation could fail? 

-How to design an institutional system which is capable of delivering good regulations? 

-How to assess regulatory quality?


####Details of the learning scenario

This course will offer a theoretical, practical and multidisciplinary approach of the phenomenon of regulation.

Every week, you will have to complete the lecture’s modules and submit a written assignment (this assignment is designed not to take you a lot of time and to verify if you grasped the main concepts of the lecture).

Workload: 72 hours

Final Assessment: Written assignement.

#### Schedule/Timetable of the learning offer

Starts: **04/03/2024**

Ends: **04/05/2024**
prerequisites:
Some interests in regulations.

Some background in Law, Political Sciences or Economics is preferable but not required.

title: British Literature and Culture I 2024
description:
Learning objectives:

Programme Description: the lecture course for students in the BA English Studies programme offers an overview of British literature and culture from the medieval period to the beginning of the Victorian era. Its aim is to provide basic information about the socio-cultural environment in which major cultural and literary events took place. The course is held by three instructors, depending on the topic at hand. The course relies on primary readings and highly recommended reference materials, which are made available online for students.

General objectives: students completing this survey course will 
--have an overview of British literary history from the Middle Ages to the Victorian period, 
--improve their analytic skills through the exploration of connections between literary texts and their different historical, social and cultural contexts, 
--be better equipped for the analysis of literary texts in a variety of genres, 
--learn about the emergence and early history of literary genres popular today, 
--make a connection between current cultural, medial and literary events and trends, and their literary-historical precedents. 

Short-term achievements: 
By attending the lecture course, students will gain information on the best canonical writers, their works, and the historical and cultural contexts of the discussed literary periods. The assessment of the course will be based on a final written exam covering the topics discussed during the sessions as well as the primary readings.

Long-term achievements: 
The course is an essential part of the English Studies BA programme. Teaching literary histories is part of the curricula of English Studies programmes in BA courses in Europe. We plan to reach undergraduate students from the universities participating in the EDUC consortium. The lecture course will contribute to their knowledge of English literary and cultural studies of which this lecture course on British Literature and Culture I is an essential part. 

Details of the learning scenario:

Starting date: 12th February, for the students of EDUC: 21st February, 2024
Ending date: 12th May, 2024
Days of teaching: Wednesdays, 16:00-17:30
Consultation days: at a pre-arranged time
Please consider a work-load per week of: 2 hours
This learning offer is “mixed”, which means that the lectures will be held on MS Teams while the materials will be uploaded to Moodle.

Evaluation period: 13th May - 21st June, 2024.

Teachers: Dr. Gabriella Hartvig (University of Pécs), Dr. Filip Bul Krajník (Masaryk University Brno), Dr. Csaba Maczelka (University of Pécs)

title: European Law : politics in the EU (2023-2024)
description:
####Learning objectives

**This course will give an overview of several fields of competences of the European Union.**
It will aim at offering a better comprehension of the concrete actions carried out by the EU.

After describing the political finality and the specificity of the original community project, it will analyze the different scope of competencies of the EU, illustrating the hybrid nature of the EU, as a mix of supranational and intergovernmental organization.

The selected topics will highlight the three different types of competences of the EU (exclusive/shared/supporting competences): 

-**Internal market**

-**Economic and monetary union**

By covering economic as well as political tasks of the EU, the course will reexamine the role and the results of the method of European integration commonly known as **"spillover effect"** or ** "functionalism"**.

####Details of the learning scenario

Emphasis will be put on current developments. Critical discussion will be encouraged.

Workload: 66h

Final assessment: online test


#### Schedule/Timetable of the learning offer

Starts: **04/03/2024**

Ends: **24/05/2024**
